node.text: <color=#9C8C77>*Only a simple stone cairn, placed here long ago, marks this humble grave. This is the place by the large stone, near the edge of the woods, as described by Bod's diary. Alyssa's husband must be buried here.*</color>

<color=#9C8C77>*As your shovel shifts the dirt, you begin to notice the grave isn't very deep. Soon you uncover a skeletal hand. Something glimmering in the skeleton's finger catches your eye.*</color>

<color=#9C8C77>*It's an old wedding ring, on the surface it's quite plain. But then you notice something carved onto the inner side of the ring: ''Love eternally - Robert and Alyssa''. You slip the ring into your pockets, confident it will serve as one of the ritual's ingredients.*</color>
The rage is gone... I feel like I have awoken from a really long nightmare!
That's not far from the truth, lady Alyssa. You've been set free from the grips of a terrible curse. The sanctity of death has been protected, and for that we have Lord Aercrest here to thank.
You did what neither I nor young Emil could accomplish. Although you do not belong to our order, you've more than carried out the duty of a real Dreamguard Champion - for that, I honor you!

option.optiontext: How are you feeling, Alyssa? You've been a spirit of vengeance in this place for a long time.
Feels like a shame a young Dreamguard knight had to die for this...
Any last piece of advice from an Elder Dreamguard, for a fellow undead stuck in this world?
So, what happens to you now?

node.text: My memories are murky from the time since I performed the ritual in that dark spellbook. I remember being so angry, I wanted the Warden to suffer, like he had made me suffer...! But then I only remember glimpses and flashes, like I wasn't really myself anymore, but an avatar of the anger I felt...
Now the anger has faded and I only feel overwhelming exhaustion. I'd welcome the peaceful sleep of death gladly. Do you think it will be possible for me to feel that, after what I've done here...?

It is my belief that you equally suffered the punishment of the dark curse when you unleashed it, therefore the Dream will not punish you further. What we face in our final sleep is more determined by our character than individual mistakes. In this way the Dream is just.

Within the Dream, I believe you will find the life from before you faced your tragedies. Sometimes it is even possible the Dream shows you moments from a life you could have had, had it not been so viciously robbed from you. Fear not, we shall guide you there to your final rest, Emil and I.

option.optiontext: Feels like a shame a young Dreamguard knight had to die for this...
Any last piece of advice from an Elder Dreamguard, for a fellow undead stuck in this world?
So, what happens to you now?

node.text: Ah, but do not feel pity, for I died proudly fulfilling my duty. I do not believe my death was in vain. I was able to resist the the maddening corruption of the curse long enough for you to come along, so that I was able to give you some measure of guidance.

And now, thanks to you, I will be able to take my place within the Dream, where I belong. If not for your triumph here, there is no telling how long I would have remained stuck here, nor what would have become of my mind.

option.optiontext: Any last piece of advice from an Elder Dreamguard, for a fellow undead stuck in this world?
How are you feeling, Alyssa? You've been a spirit of vengeance in this place for a long time.
So, what happens to you now?

node.text: <color=#9C8C77>*For the first time since your defeat of the Ghost of Greywall, the Dreamguard Champion looks troubled. He ponders your question for a moment.*</color>

You must understand, for the Dreamguard, defiling the sanctity of the dead is a crime of the highest order. The existence of True Undead - souls brought back from the Dream - is an often debated topic, but thus far it has been a purely philosophical one. There are no accounts of Dreamguard ever encountering such True Undead.

That isn't to say there aren't, nor ever have been, others. But to my knowledge your condition is unique, and can only have been the cause of magic of such severity I cannot even begin to imagine. Souls of the dead belong nowhere else except for the Dream. I do not know how, or when... but having witnessed your tenacity here, I have faith your soul too will one day find its way back home.

option.optiontext: Hold on, what exactly is the difference between myself and other undead I have slain?
Weren't the souls trapped in this place True Undead though?
I see, thank you.

node.text: Regular undead are merely the animated bodies of souls, whose rest within the Dream has for some reason or another become disturbed. Sometimes this is done on purpose for nefarious reasons, and those who would consider themselves necromancers seek command of these bodies. But always they are mindless, their souls ultimately safeguarded within the Dream.

option.optiontext: Weren't the souls trapped here True Undead though?
I see, thank you.

node.text: In a manner of speaking, though the circumstances surrounding Greywall were highly unique also. But you must understand, the undead souls here were never granted passage into the Dream to begin with. Now that the curse trapping them here is gone, the souls are free to move on. In time they will do so, and these dungeons will quieten.

option.optiontext: Hold on, what exactly is the difference between myself and other undead I have slain?
I see, thank you.

node.text: Though we yearn to enter eternal rest, we'll gladly linger a moment in your company, Lord Aercrest.

option.optiontext: How are you feeling, Alyssa? You've been a spirit of vengeance in this place for a long time.
Feels like a shame a young Dreamguard knight had to die for this...
Any last piece of advice from an Elder Dreamguard, for a fellow undead stuck in this world?
So, what happens to you now?

node.text: Now we are finally free! The way into the Dream is open to us all, though I cannot guess how long it will take the other souls in these dungeons to realize this. But given time, I'm certain the halls of these dungeons will fall still.
As for you, lady Alyssa, we may perform one final service as the Dreamguard. Come, it is time to go home - let us escort you there.

Oh, one more thing before I go; keep an eye out for a lavish chest, as you leave down this corridor, hero! I believe the corrupt Warden stashed all sorts of goods there, kept it hidden in this most secure part of the dungeon.

Souls of our ancestors be praised, it has been some time since I sent you on the grave task of investigating the Dungeons of Greywall! I had grown to think that perhaps you too, like the Dreamguard who entered before you, had perished within its halls...
Dare I presume you braved the cursed underground halls? Dare I hope you have vanquished the source of evil trapped within?

option.optiontext: The Curse of Greywall is no more, given time its halls will fall silent of the undead.

node.text: You cannot know how much hearing this news brings relief upon my ageing heart. The task I entrusted upon you was not an easy one, yet I knew it had to be done, and you were my only hope left in these lands. For carrying out this duty, on behalf of our order, I declare you Champion of the Dead!

option.optiontext: I found the missing Dreamguard warriors within the dungeons, both perished I'm afraid...
The curse was, as you suspected, complex and centered around Alyssa - a woman who had been terribly wronged by the Warden of Greywall.
I'm honored... well, there it is.

node.text: Ah, that is a great shame indeed... not unexpected, but a tragedy nonetheless. I shall perform prayers for their souls this night to help guide their journey into the Dream. In breaking Greywall's Curse, I believe you saved their souls also from a dreadful fate? It is yet another thing for which our order owes you a debt of gratitude.

option.optiontext: The curse was, as you suspected, complex and centered around Alyssa - a woman who had been terribly wronged by the Warden of Greywall.
As you say... well, there it is.

node.text: Indeed? I trust in breaking the curse, you also helped her troubled soul gain a measure of peace and rest. Hm, 'dark deeds beget a dark inheritance', such were the words of High Dreamseer Marcus Stillwater, my bygone teacher. Words I often find myself retelling, as I find they hold much truth both in life and in death.

option.optiontext: I found the missing Dreamguard warriors within the dungeons, both perished I'm afraid...
Wise words... well, there it is.

node.text: Thank you for bringing me this news, Champion. I had requested a sum of gold from our monasteries in Melloria, so that I have more than words to offer for my gratitude. The reward is yours, of course, as it is well deserved. May the spirits of those who came before us ever light your path, Champion!

<color=#9C8C77>*As you turn to walk away from the priest, you recall the ritual spellbook from the dungeons - whatever happened to it? You rummage through your bags and find it hidden somewhere in their bottom folds, forgotten in all the excitement.*</color>

<color=#9C8C77>*Aside from Greywall's curse, the book does detail other, minor incantations. They promise great power, but the Witches' magic always comes at a cost. Dare you make use of them...?*</color>

May benevolent spirits always watch over you, Champion of the Dead. The Order of the Sleeping Souls will not forget the service you have provided. I've sent word of your exploits to our monasteries in Melloria - among our ranks you're considered a friend.

option.optiontext: Wanted to talk to you about Greywall...
Wanted to ask about your duties as a priest...

node.text: Certainly, though I imagine by now you know far more about those ruins than I. A site with a dark past, and presently not safe either according to reports, but one can always hope it may one day yet have a brighter future.

option.optiontext: What do you know about the place from before it became haunted?
About the Dreamguard Knights who perished in Greywall...
Let's talk about your duties as a priest instead.
Nevermind, peace be with you, priest.

node.text: It was a remote dungeons I believe, set up by the tyrant Goldbridge after overthrowing the previous ruling family in these lands, the Aercrests. Mind you, this is not history I know very well, you might learn more in a library.

Many decades ago, it is told, something dark and mysterious happened. Overnight all souls within the prison were slain, without any signs of a battle or bloodshed. They had simply died... and so the dungeons were promptly sealed.

Of course, as you uncovered, we know it became the site of a terrible curse. One that you helped put down, and in so doing I believe you gave a chance for all the restless dead trapped within the halls of Greywall, that they may eventually find peace again.

option.optiontext: About the Dreamguard Knights who perished in Greywall...
Wanted to ask about your duties as a priest...
Peace be with you, priest.

node.text: Do not fret, their souls are safe thanks to you. I've made my prayers for them, and though I'm no Dreamseer, I am confident they now rest within the warm embrace of the Dream. It was your actions that saved them from a terrible fate, and our Order will not forget that.

option.optiontext: What do you know about the place from before it became haunted?
Wanted to ask about your duties as a priest...
Peace be with you, priest.

node.text: Indeed, I belong to the Order of the Sleeping Souls, whose service honors the ones who Dream, though of course our duties also extend to those of us who remain awake. Our numbers are still few in these lands, but here I serve at the site of this old shrine.

option.optiontext: Those who dream and those who remain awake, what do you mean exactly?
Tell me about the Order.
What is this place - the old shrine?
Let's talk about Greywall instead.
Of course, peace be with you, priest.

node.text: I speak of the Dream, of course. Here in this world we wake and when it is our time to pass, we fall asleep and dream of the things that once were.

option.optiontext: And what role do you play in the afterlife?
Had another question...
Peace be with you, priest.

node.text: Ah, you must be under the impression that the Dream is somehow separate from our world. That it is only for the dead, as our world is only for the living. But it is not so.

Our worlds are intertwined and when the sleeping ones are restless, so may their remains in this world begin to stir. It is thus important to ease a soul's passage to the Dream, to bless them in their slumber. And it is a crime most heinous to disturb them in their sleep.

option.optiontext: So what would you say if a soul was ripped from the Dream and returned to this life? Somehow through the use magic, for example.
Had another question...
Peace be with you, priest.

node.text: That would be an act most foul and abominable! Please, I implore you, do not even speak of such things!

option.optiontext: But could the victim be helped?
Had another question...
Peace be with you, priest.

node.text: Hmph... well... I suppose, such awakened undead should be returned to their place within the Dream, but it is beyond me to speculate how. If they were thus violated through magic, I suspect only magic could mend their condition.

option.optiontext: Had another question...
Peace be with you, priest.

node.text: Though our presence here in Imberthale is young, our Order has a long history within the lands of Melloria. We began with a humble monastery in Cleric's Cliff, overlooking the sea, several centuries ago. These days Cleric's Cliff is a bustling city, of course, the halls of the monastery have become many times expanded.

option.optiontext: What does the order do?
Had another question...
Peace be with you, priest.

node.text: We bless both the living and the dead. Some among us have the power to peer into the Dream - the Dreamseers - who may even converse with the souls of our ancestors. They form an important connection with our past, and are thus able to recall memories long lost to time.

Sadly, there are always those in the waking world who would disturb the sleeping ones. Our blessings alone are not always enough to ward against such transgressions, and sometimes the dead begin to stir in their sleep. This why some among us must take upon them the responsibility of becoming the Dreamguard.

option.optiontext: Tell me about the Dreamguard.
Had another question...
Peace be with you, priest.

node.text: Indeed, the warrior caste of our order. Their purpose it is to seek the restless dead and return them to their peaceful slumber. Punishment must also be meted to those who defiled the sleep of the dead in the first place. Death is often the sentence.

option.optiontext: Grim, by whose authority?
Had another question...
Peace be with you, priest.

node.text: Their cause is just, they need no permission. Though perhaps not always everyone agrees, and sometimes tensions have risen. The Dreamguard are not always best liked, but their task is ever so important regardless.

option.optiontext: Had another question...
Peace be with you, priest.

node.text: Curious about the shrine, eh? It was not built by my order, but it has always been here according to the locals. I do not doubt their word - Imberthale is a place for many old things.

Beyond that, I'm afraid I don't know much more about it than you do. But whatever purpose this shrine served in the past, there is a peace to it that I like. It felt natural to take up my duties here.

option.optiontext: Had another question...
Peace be with you, priest.

node.text: Of course, whatever do you wish to know, Champion of the Dead?

option.optiontext: Those who dream and those who remain awake, what do you mean exactly?
Tell me about the Order.
What is this place - the old shrine?
Let's talk about Greywall instead.
Nevermind, peace be with you, priest.

node.text: It all just happened so fast...

option.optiontext: What now?

node.text: Hm? Oh, sorry stranger. I was lost in deep thought. Happens to me a lot lately. Shouldn't be surprising I guess, seeing as I witnessed all my friends die just the other morning...

option.optiontext: Woah, what happened?
I'm sorry to hear that...

node.text: We worked the Sallowstone Mine, near those old Greywall ruins everyone says are haunted. Was a day like any other, we'd all just walked inside, ready to start, is when I remember I'd forgot to bring my lunch...

So I run off to retrieve it and, so... out of nowhere this shockwave just runs through the land. No idea what's caused it, but as I get back on my feet and turn, I see the mine behind me... only it's completely collapsed, almost everyone I know buried within...

option.optiontext: You were the only survivor?
I'm so sorry, I'll leave you to it...

node.text: Wait, erm... you're not afraid of death, are you stranger? See, it's not the collapse of the mine that has me as bothered as what's happened after. My friends, they didn't go peacefully, understand?

Soon after the mine collapsed they sprang up as ghosts, I couldn't believe my eyes! I tried to talk to them of course, but they were, erm... confused-like, not friendly at all. Erm, dare I ask you give it a go?

option.optiontext: Why, what do you expect them to say?
Where should I look for this mine?
If I come across them, I can certainly try.

node.text: Well I dunno, but I want my friends to be at peace - it's what they deserve. It's not normal for folk to turn into angry ghosts as they die, you know. If they'd just tell what it is they want, we could appease them, let them pass onto their world in the Dream.

option.optiontext: Where should I look for this mine?
Sure, I'll give it a try.

node.text: The Sallowstone Mine is where we worked... It's in the woods, when you follow the road due east from the village entrance. I'll mark it on your map...

option.optiontext: What do you expect ghosts to say?
Sure, I'll give it a try.

node.text: It is much appreciated. Wish I could do it myself, but you look much more able to deal with angry ghosts than I. Please let me know if you find out what they want.
Yeah, I was... and now I get to feel guilty for it for the rest of my life, I reckon...

option.optiontext: I'm so sorry, I'll leave you to it...

node.text: Greetings to you again. Have you spoken to the ghosts of my friends down at the mine? Do you know what they want?

option.optiontext: I spoke with the ghosts, but I only made them upset.

I don't know yet.

What are you expecting the ghosts to say?
I should go.

node.text: But I still can't help feeling like there's something we must be able to do...! Perhaps what we need is an expert. There's a priesthood that knows about all matters of life beyond death. I've heard one of them keeps service at the old shrine north of Haywind.
If you come by him on your travels, please speak to him about what's happened here - he must know how to help.

option.optiontext: Very well.

node.text: There's nothing to it, just gotta get back to work, gotta fix it all y'know...

option.optiontext: It's too late to fix anything, you're a ghost and need to pass on - let me help you.

node.text: No, you're not making any sense... Why would you say that? Who do you think you are?! This is my mine, my rules! You don't tell me how to run my mine! You need to leave, now!!

option.actions: SetVar=Q97Samuel-1,NpcChat=Who do you think you are?! You need to leave!

node.text: My husband's in there! Somebody help, somebody please...!!

option.optiontext: Um, hate to break this to you but I think you were in there too...

node.text: What... what are you talking about? No, you need to listen to me! You need to help my husband!

option.optiontext: If you'd just tell me how I can help you move on...

node.text: What...? Don't you care about my husband? How can you be so callous?! You need to leave, now!!

option.optiontext: Um, what...?

node.text: I just wanted to be a miner, like my pa... was just meant to help out here for a while, before transferring to the big mines in Silderstone... it wasn't meant to be like this!

option.optiontext: So you're aware you're dead, excellent.

node.text: Excellent? What's excellent about it?! This is a nightmare!

option.optiontext: I only meant that you can help me to help you move on.

node.text: There is no moving on... there's only darkness and despair... You're not helping me! You can't help me! Get away, stop tormenting me!

option.optiontext: Come now, please...

node.text: Can't just abandon them to their fate. Can't imagine what it's like being stuck here as a ghost after death.

node.text: If anyone knows how to appease the souls of the dead, it's that Priesthood of the Sleeping Souls. I've heard one among their ranks maintains a service at an old shrine north of Haywind. Maybe you could ask his opinion when you happen to travel in his direction?

option.optiontext: Tell me again, what happened to your friends?
I can try.

node.text: Greetings to you again. Did you seek out the priest? Is there any hope for the ghosts of my friends?

option.optiontext: Perhaps... together with the priest we created a lantern to soothe dead spirits.
I'm working on it...

node.text: So there is hope! That is welcome news, I knew the priest would know what to do! Well, have you tried it, the lantern - does it work?

option.optiontext: I'll let you know as soon as I've returned to the mine.

node.text: Indeed? Word of the mine's collapse did reach me here as well. All the miners within were slain, I was told... most unfortunate business.
node.contextBefore: I've encountered angry ghosts near a collapsed mine down south...

node.text: Now you tell me the souls of the miners have risen as ghosts? And this happens down south, near the old ruins of Greywall... Most curious, hmm... curious, and troubling indeed...

option.optiontext: Why, what do you know of it?

node.text: There are rumors that something lurks within Greywall, haunting the place. A champion of our order, the Dreamguard Jorune Drey Ryefeldt, was called from Melloria to investigate. Nothing was heard from him since...

Soon after his apprentice, who was presumed to have gone looking for him, also disappeared. I fear something very dark indeed lurks within the shadows of Greywall. And from what you say, it may be spreading its corruption.

option.optiontext: What is Greywall?
These Dreamguard of yours - they disappeared?
Let's get back to the ghosts - how do I appease them?

node.text: It was a remote dungeons I believe, set up by the tyrant Goldbridge after overthrowing the previous ruling family in these lands, the Aercrests. Mind you, this is not history I know very well, you might learn more in a library.

Many decades ago, it is told, something dark and mysterious happened. Overnight all souls within the prison were slain, without any signs of a battle or bloodshed. They had simply died... and so the dungeons were promptly sealed.

option.optiontext: These Dreamguard of yours - they disappeared?
Let's get back to the ghosts - how do I appease them?

node.text: I directed Jorune towards the dungeons myself. I may well have been the last person to speak to him alive. It is a shame too, since your ghost problem is precisely the kind of thing the Dreamguard are equipped to deal with. None more are available in these lands.

option.optiontext: What is Greywall?
Let's get back to the ghosts - how do I appease them?

node.text: We must send them on their way to the Dream, where they belong. However, I am not the person to face fearsome undead in battle - that's what the Dreamguard are for - but I may be able to grant to you my blessing to appease them.

<color=#9C8C77>*The priest quickly scribbles a note and hands it to you.*</color>\n\nWe shall need but a vessel to carry the power of my incantations. There's an exceptional craftsman down in the city named Opticus Aluminar, present my note to him and he may be able to help.

option.optiontext: Ah, I already happen to be well acquanted with the man.
Where would I find his workshop?

node.text: Indeed? Then you know his workshop is near the old quarry, far southwest of the city. Once you have the appropriate vessel, bring it to me and I shall bless it.

option.optiontext: Very well.

node.text: It is far southwest within the city, near the old quarry. Once you have the appropriate vessel, bring it to me and I shall bless it.

option.optiontext: Very well.

node.text: I can tell you what I know, though I must stress my knowledge on those ruins is not very extensive.

option.optiontext: You say it's an abandoned ruin, but what was it exactly?
Do you think the ruins are really haunted?

node.text: It was a remote dungeons I believe, set up by the tyrant Goldbridge after overthrowing the previous ruling family in these lands, the Aercrests. Mind you, this is not history I know very well, you might learn more in a library.

Many decades ago, it is told, something dark and mysterious happened. Overnight all souls within the prison were slain, without any signs of a battle or bloodshed. They had simply died... and so the dungeons were promptly sealed.

option.optiontext: Do you think the ruins are really haunted?
I see.

node.text: Certainly there are rumors that something lurks within Greywall, haunting the place. A champion of our order, the Dreamguard Jorune Drey Ryefeldt was called from Melloria to investigate. Nothing was heard from him since...

Soon after that his apprentice, who was presumed to have gone looking for him, also disappeared. Considering what you told me of ghosts arising at the collapsed mine near Greywall, I fear something very dark indeed may lurk within its shadows.

option.optiontext: But what is Greywall, exactly?
I see.

node.text: That a fact? You'd be better off talking to a priest if I'm honest. Once tried building a contraption that sucked ghosts into a container, it did not end up well for anyone involved...

option.optiontext: As it happens, I bear a note from a priest asking for your help.
Really, what happened?
I'm meant to bring you a note explaining everything, but I seem to have lost it...

node.text: A long story, let me just say a gateway opened into another dimension, which threatened to release a creature that might have leveled the whole city... been reluctant to meddle in otherwordly matters since.

option.optiontext: In any case, I bear a note from a priest asking for your help.
I'm meant to bring you a note explaining everything, but I seem to have lost it...

node.text: <color=#9C8C77>*The inventor takes the note from you and reads it over, all the while muttering to himself. Finally, he speaks up...*</color>

All right then, seems simple enough. Leaves all the otherwordly stuff to the priest, just needs the proper vessel to carry his power. I have a lantern of sorts in mind, but you'll have to be the one to craft it.

option.optiontext: Can't you do it?
That's fine, just tell me what I need.

node.text: What with Hubert messing up my workshop, I can't very well right now. But what I can do is give you the blueprints and tell you where to get the materials you need.

option.optiontext: Let's go over the materials then.

node.text: First off we'll want just the right wood for the frame, Wildsfir should do the trick. Some of it grows in Prowler's Thicket as far as I know, southwest of Thornhill.
Some iron fittings are also required, lots of places you could get iron I reckon. Heard recently a miner struck some veins in a cave along the road to Thornshill, could give it a look.

<color=#9C8C77>*Opticus teaches you the blueprints for the Priest's Lantern and you carefully write his instructions down into your journal.*</color>\n\nOnce you got all that, you'll just need to find yourself a proper workbench, one like they'll have at the crafter's guild near Haywind marketsquare. Good luck, mate!
